Physical Exam: Inspection of the right calf for swelling, discoloration, or deformities.
Justification: To assess for any visible signs of injury, swelling, or abnormalities that may indicate a deeper issue such as a blood clot or muscle strain.

Physical Exam: Palpation of the right calf to assess tenderness and temperature.
Justification: To determine the specific areas of pain and to check for warmth or tenderness that may suggest inflammation or a clot.

Physical Exam: Assessment of range of motion in the ankle and knee joints.
Justification: To evaluate if there is any limitation in movement due to pain or swelling.

Physical Exam: Dorsiflexion test (Homan's sign) to check for pain in the calf.
Justification: To assess for signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT), although this test is not definitive.

Physical Exam: Comparison of the right calf with the left calf for size and temperature.
Justification: To identify any asymmetry or differences that may indicate swelling or vascular issues.

Physical Exam: Check for pulses in the dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial arteries.
Justification: To evaluate the blood flow to the lower extremities and rule out vascular compromise.
